all_questions.question: What are the advantages of modifying language models to look at morphological text instead of word forms?
all_questions.context: So now what are the advantages if we modify our language models so that they don't look at word forms but instead they look rather at the morphological text.

all_questions.question: How does a language model trained on sufficiently large data handle the comparison of different translation candidates?
all_questions.context: So if we're considering the probability of the bigram-two kočkách which is wrong that doesn't agree versus the probability of the phrase-two kočky which is linguistically grammatically correct there is the agreement then a reasonable language model trained on sufficiently large data would know it

all_questions.question: What is the benefit of using morphological text in language models compared to word forms?
all_questions.context: So these probabilities that are trained on morphological text will be observed on many more instances of any noun and any adjective and therefore they will be estimated much more reliably

all_questions.question: In what way do language models handle cases where the form and meaning of a word are not agreed?
all_questions.context: So here the language model will obviously not help. But we are still getting the benefit that the vocabulary size of these morphological text is much smaller

all_questions.question: How does the use of morphological text affect the overall grammatical coherence in a sentence?
all_questions.context: And with this smaller vocabulary we can afford to use much longer engrams. So we can use of word forms and that gives the system quite a power about the overall grammatical coherence in the sentence
